sense.name: an injury caused by biting from teeth
sense.commentary: BITE[+form][+flaw][+injury][+from_teeth] Note: refers to a physical area that is damaged, not an event (Sense 8)
sense.examples: The two puncture holes on his leg look like a snake bite. The girl had a dog bite on her hand, but it was not serious. It was a shark bite that required 400 stitches.

sense.name: an insect sting
sense.examples: The child scratched at his mosquito bites. Bob got a bad reaction from a wasp bite.

sense.name: mouthful-sized amount of food
sense.examples: Mary gave John a bite of her dessert. Tom ate his hot dog in three bites, but Pete ate his in five. She fed the baby the banana in tiny bites.

sense.name: light, informal snack
sense.examples: We stopped at a cafe for a late-night bite after the performance. Do you want to grab a bite in the cafeteria before our meeting? There was not a bite to eat anywhere in the airport after 10 pm.

sense.name: the act of snapping at bait by a fish
sense.examples: The fisherman felt a bite on his line. The boy thought he had a bite, but his fishing rod had just snagged a branch.

sense.name: a caustic remark
sense.examples: His comments had the bite of satire. He ignored her bites at his past performance and talked about the future.

sense.name: having a pungent or sharp flavor
sense.examples: This chili has quite a bite to it from all the hot peppers. John enjoys the pungent bite of southeast Asian cuisine. The screenplay has a tepid plot that lacks any real bite. (figurative extension)

sense.name: the act of chomping or tearing at something with the teeth
sense.commentary: BITE[+event][+gripping][+chomping][+with_teeth] Note: refers to the act of biting, not the resulting wound (Sense 1)
sense.examples: The shark's bite severed the swimmer's arm. That dog's bark is worse than his bite. Let's take a bite out of crime. (figurative extension)

sense.name: a portion of a greater whole
sense.examples: The feds are taking a bigger bite out of personal income this year. Inflation can take a bite out of your retirement funds.

sense.name: a brief reporting of information
sense.examples: The evening news had a few sound bites from the debate.

sense.name: an icy or cold sensation
sense.examples: There was a real bite to the December air.

sense.name: the position of a person's upper and lower teeth brought together
sense.examples: The dentist told Sally she had a perfect bite. The child is wearing braces on his teeth to improve his bite.
